title: Understanding $$ \cup _{rms}$$
text: The root mean square velocity (U_rms) of a gas is related to its temperature and molar mass. It is given by the formula: $$ \cup _{rms}=\sqrt{\frac{3R T}{M}}$$, where R is the gas constant, T is the temperature in Kelvin, and M is the molar mass of the gas.

title: Effect of Molar Mass on $$ \cup _{rms}$$
text: Notice that $$ \cup _{rms}$$ is inversely proportional to the square root of the molar mass (M). This means that gases with lower molar masses will have higher $$ \cup _{rms}$$ values at the same temperature.

title: Comparing Molar Masses
text: To determine which gas has the highest $$ \cup _{rms}$$, compare the molar masses of $$N_2$$, $$H_2 S$$, and $$SO_2$$. The gas with the smallest molar mass will have the highest $$ \cup _{rms}$$.

title: Calculating Molar Masses
text: Calculate the molar masses: $$N_2$$ (28 g/mol), $$H_2 S$$ (34 g/mol), and $$SO_2$$ (64 g/mol).

title: Identifying the Gas with Highest $$ \cup _{rms}$$
text: Based on the molar masses, identify which gas has the smallest molar mass and therefore the highest $$ \cup _{rms}$$.
